objinfo.medium: Pencil, pen and ink, with touches of gray wash
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe bottom margin is inscribed in pencil, "24" and "Blake". Neither inscription is by Blake. Butlin 644 reports that the verso is inscribed "The Original Drawing of Blake's Last Judgment", possibly by Frederick Tatham.
objinfo.framelines: 1A single framing line in pen and ink extends around the design.

provenance.name: Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas
provenance.note: By inheritance to Catherine Blake upon William Blake's death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 179 with two other Last Judgment designs by Blake, Butlin 643 and Butlin 646 or 647 (15s. to the dealer H. Palser); Alfred Aspland by 1876; sold from Aspland's collection, Sotheby's, 27 Jan. 1885, lot 64, this work only (£1 to Edward Riggall); sold from Riggall's collection, Sotheby's, 4 July 1901, lot 65 (£3 to the dealer Ward acting for Sidney Cockerell); sold from Cockerell's collection, Christie's, 25 July 1952, lot 26 (£136.10s. to the dealer Jacob Schwartz, probably acting for T. Edward Hanley); possibly given by Hanley to Amy E. Miles in 1961, according to a note written on the backing mat; acquired in 1967 by the New York dealer House of El Dieff and offered in their 1969 catalogue 70, item 16 ($10,000), but apparently already sold in 1967 to the Humanities Research Center (now Harry Ransom Center), University of Texas, Austin, Texas.

repository.institution: Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas

objnote.p: The composition is very similar to Butlin 645, [*The Last Judgment*](http://www.blakearchive.org/preview/but645) in the National Gallery of Art, Washington, and may be a preliminary drawing for that more finished work.
